awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Toward Structure-Based Models of Chiral Recognition by Amino Acid Based Macromolecular Assemblies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program in the Division of Chemistry. Professors Billiot and Billiot of Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi, Kevin Morris of Carthage College, and Yayin Fang of Howard University form a multi-institutional collaboration. The work focuses on the investigation and elucidation of the factors responsible for molecular self-assembly, and how these factors affect the ability of the self-assembled molecular structures to interact and recognize other molecules of biological importance. A variety of experimental and computational methods are used to developed Quantitative Structure Enantioselective Retention Relationships (QSERR). QSERR is then used to evaluate and compare the effectiveness of different chiral selectors for capillary electrophoretic separations. Two of the three institutions are primarily undergraduate institutions that currently do not have a master's program in chemistry. Thus, the research will be conducted at these two schools exclusively by undergraduate students. One of these is also a Hispanic Serving Institution. The third university involved in the research is an HBCU. The research serves as a tool for the PIs to recruit, train, and mentor students from underrepresented and economically challenged backgrounds and to encourage these students to pursue post baccalaureate degrees in science.  

The proposed research is part of an ongoing, long-term multi-faceted study focusing on investigating and elucidating the factors responsible for (a) self-assembly, (b) function, (c) higher ordered structure and (d) molecular recognition of amino acid based macromolecular assemblies (AABMAs). In particular, the research will focus on examining the effects that pH, ionic strength, surfactant concentration, and type of counter-ion have on the factors mentioned above. These AABMAs are being utilized in this study as chiral pseudostationary phases in capillary electrophoresis. Thus, the major focus of these studies is to gain insights into the factors responsible for chiral recognition with this class of chiral selector. A deeper understanding of these factors will lead to enhanced chiral separations and improved pseudostationary phases. Understanding such interactions is not only important in the development of chiral recognition media but also in the optimization of the separation conditions. In addition, since enantiorecognition of the systems under study are amino acids, the knowledge gained from these studies will be potentially transferable to other amino acid based systems such as proteins.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins which in turn catalyze most reactions in cells. Therefore, an understanding of how amino acids behave and interact with other molecules is of critical importance to the scientific community as well as to clinical medicine. The research funded by this award studied amino acid-based macromolecular assemblies.  In these materials, amino acids or small peptides are covalently bound to a hydrophobic hydrocarbon chain.  These molecules then self-assemble into either spherical or cylindrical aggregates. The resulting amino acid-based macromolecular assemblies can disperse oils and other non-polar compounds in water, thus they have applications in the detergent, cosmetics, and petroleum industries.  They can also recognize and selectively bind to drug molecules giving them further applications in drug delivery and separation science. Finally, amino acid based macromolecular assemblies are biodegradable, biocompatible, and can be synthesized from biomass and other sustainable materials.

In this project amino acid-based macromolecular assemblies containing glycine, alanine, valine, leucine, or phenylalanine amino acids were synthesized. Both experimental (nuclear magnetic resonance, capillary electrophoresis, fluorescence spectroscopy, and dynamic light scattering) and computational studies were performed.  Properties investigated included how the assemblies? molecular recognition ability was affected by pH, concentration, and type of positive counterion bound to the negative assembly surface. These counterions included linear and cyclic diamines and the amino acids arginine and leucine.

Discoveries made in these studies included the observation that the macromolecular assemblies formed at lower concentrations when diamine and amino acids were present in solution and at higher concentration when metal ions like sodium were present.  Therefore, the amines and amino acids served as templating agents that facilitated assembly formation.  Furthermore, linear diamines and the amino acid lysine were found to bind parallel to the surface of the assemblies.  Arginine and cyclic diamines instead bound perpendicular to the surface.  The structures of the counterion molecules present in solution were also found to affect the assemblies? ability to separate drug molecules in complex mixtures. Finally, computational studies provided insight into how the assemblies recognized and selectively bound to drug molecules like propranolol and lorazepam.

The research was a collaborative effort between three universities: Texas A&M University Corpus Christi (TAMUCC), Howard University and Carthage College. These Universities are, respectively a Hispanic Serving Institution, a Historically Black College (HBCU) and an undergraduate school with no STEM graduate programs.  Thus, due to the nature of the student demographics, most of the undergraduate researchers at all three institutions were either female or first-generation students.

During this grant TAMUCC had a total 12 graduate (Chemistry Master?s) students and 16 undergraduate students working on various aspects of the research.  All of the students involved in this project, unless they were very new to the research group are authors or coauthors of manuscripts and/or have presented at regional and/or national meetings/conferences. The research has resulted in 8 published manuscripts, and one to be submitted in the next few months. The research has also resulted in 43 presentations at regional and/or national meetings/conferences Note that as part of the opportunities for training and professional development, each of the students were expected to give presentations at least once during the semester at our weekly group meeting.  In addition, each of the students were assigned specific instrumental, synthetic techniques, or molecular modeling techniques which they were to become the ?expert? in the group on.  They were then expected to learn as much about that technique as they could and then they were given responsibility for training others.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Eugene J Billiot
